Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Controls on along-strike variations in locked and creeping megathrust behavior at the Hikurangi convergent margin
Award.AbstractNarration: The physical processes dictating the spectrum of fault slip modes (spanning destructive earthquakes<br/>to slow slip events and aseismic creep) and the links between these behaviors and long-term<br/>morphotectonic evolution of subduction systems are not understood. There is a fundamental<br/>need to address this important problem with an integrated, system-level approach combining<br/>geodynamical modeling with high-quality geophysical and geological constraints on subduction<br/>margin characteristics.<br/><br/>This project will conduct an interdisciplinary, multinational collaborative program involving the USA, New Zealand, Japan and the UK to evaluate system-level controls on processes that govern both slip behavior and long-term deformation at subduction zones. The focus is on the Hikurangi margin in New Zealand, where GPS data show a transition in slip behavior from predominantly stick-slip<br/>in the south to aseismic creep in the northern North Island, and where a wide range of subduction-related<br/>processes and characteristics vary along-strike. The aim is to rigorously investigate the feedbacks<br/>between plate interface slip behavior, solid and fluid mass fluxes, and manifestations of plate boundary mechanics in the long-term geological record that likely reflect common driving processes linking forearc uplift, sediment transfer and underplating, plate boundary strength, and seismogenesis. The Principal Investigators will address this important problem through an integrated approach combining large-scale seismic imaging, paleoseismology, and geomorphology, focused through the lens of state-of-the-art numerical modelling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to deepen our understanding of earthquake behavior on sunbduction zone plate boundaries - locations where one of Earth's tectonic plates "dives" beneath another. The fault zones formed at these plate boundaries, termed "megathrusts", are responsible for many of the planet's largest, most energetic, and damaging earthquakes and tsunamis. However, detailed information about these plate boundasries, and particuarly about why some megathrusts appear to store energy and slip in damaging earthquakes, whereas others move more slowly by creeping continuously or in slow slip events, a form of slow-motion and non-damaging earthquake that unfolds over days to weeks to even months (inseat of seconds to minutes), remains elusive. The Hikurangi subduction zone, located offshore of Northern New Zealand, was chosen for this project because it exhibits a clear change along ots length, from creeping behavior in the North, to locking and stress buildup in the South.

This project was designed to combine detailed imaging of the megathrust and surrounding rock with sophisticated computer models of plate movement and stressing of the rock and sediment in the region, in order to test some of the leading ideas about factors that control slow slip events and creeping megathrust behavior. Using computer simulations of the system, we found that geometric roughness - for example, the presence of seamounts - on the subducting plate play a key role in explaining patterns of earthquakes and slip: the areas in front of seamounts are subjected to extra stresses, and are more prone to regular (fast) earthquakes. In contrast, areas behind these features lie in a "stress shadow" and should be more prone to creeping and slow slip. The modeling and imaging, taken together, also suggest an important role of fluids in promoting slow slip. These fluids are carried in thick sedimentary deposits atop the subducting plate, and thus are delivered to the slow slip source zone deeper along the megathrust. Our results show that these fluids are surprisingly abundant, and that their release may correlate with the patches of the megathrust where slow slip events initiate.
